clinical_study.brief_title: Glucose-induced Glucagon-like Peptide 1 (GLP-1) Secretion in NAFLD Patients Compared to Healthy Controls
clinical_study.official_title: Glucose-induced Glucagon-like Peptide 1 (GLP-1) Secretion in NAFLD Patients Compared to Healthy Controls

brief_summary.textblock: The incretin effect is impaired in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), thus GLP-1 receptor agonists are used for the treatment of T2DM. Insulin resistance is a pathophysiologic hallmark of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). The incretin effect in patients with NAFLD has not been studied. The aim of this study is to quantify GLP-1 secretion in response to oral glucose tolerance test (oGTT) in patients with NAFLD compared to healthy controls. The results of this study will expand the knowledge of the pathophysiology of NAFLD and serve as a rational for potential future treatment strategies.

detailed_description.textblock: Primary endpoint: GLP-1 response to oral glucose Secondary endpoints: glucose and insulin responses to oral glucose challenge

primary_outcome.measure: Glucagon-like Peptide 1 (GLP-1) secretion in response to oGTT
primary_outcome.description: The difference in GLP-1 secretion in response to oGTT as assessed by area under the curve (AUC) and peak plasma concentration (cmax) in patients with NAFLD compared to healthy controls.

secondary_outcome.measure: Insulin secretion and glucose curves in response to oGTT

intervention.description: Oral intake of 75 g glucose after overnight fast

study_pop.textblock:
Patients with biopsy proven NAFLD and NASH will be recruited from the Hepatology Outpatient Clinic, Division of Gastroenterology and Hepatology, University Hospital Basel.
Healthy control subjects will be matched to NAFLD and NASH patients.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Biopsy proven NAFLD or NASH
Exclusion Criteria:
- additional concomitants liver disease
- T2DM
- alcohol consumption >40g/d for male subjects and >20g/d for female subjects
